class.name: Vector2i
class.brief_description: Vector used for 2D math using integer coordinates.
class.description: 2-element structure that can be used to represent positions in 2D space or any other pair of numeric values. It uses integer coordinates and is therefore preferable to [Vector2] when exact precision is required. [b]Note:[/b] In a boolean context, a Vector2i will evaluate to [code]false[/code] if it's equal to [code]Vector2i(0, 0)[/code]. Otherwise, a Vector2i will always evaluate to [code]true[/code].

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a default-initialized [Vector2i] with all components set to [code]0[/code].

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a [Vector2i] as a copy of the given [Vector2i].

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a new [Vector2i] from [Vector2]. The floating point coordinates will be truncated.

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a new [Vector2i] from the given [code]x[/code] and [code]y[/code].

method.name: abs
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components in absolute values (i.e. positive).

method.name: aspect
method.description: Returns the ratio of [member x] to [member y].

method.name: clamp
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components clamped between the components of [code]min[/code] and [code]max[/code], by running [method @GlobalScope.clamp] on each component.

method.name: sign
method.description: Returns the vector with each component set to one or negative one, depending on the signs of the components.

members.member: The vector's X component. Also accessible by using the index position [code][0][/code].
The vector's Y component. Also accessible by using the index position [code][1][/code].

constants.constant: Enumerated value for the X axis.
Enumerated value for the Y axis.
Zero vector, a vector with all components set to [code]0[/code].
One vector, a vector with all components set to [code]1[/code].
Left unit vector. Represents the direction of left.
Right unit vector. Represents the direction of right.
Up unit vector. Y is down in 2D, so this vector points -Y.
Down unit vector. Y is down in 2D, so this vector points +Y.

operator.name: operator !=
operator.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if the vectors are not equal.

operator.name: operator %
operator.description: Gets the remainder of each component of the [Vector2i] with the components of the given [Vector2i]. This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [method @GlobalScope.posmod] instead if you want to handle negative numbers. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, -20) % Vector2i(7, 8)) # Prints "(3, -4)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator %
operator.description: Gets the remainder of each component of the [Vector2i] with the the given [int]. This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [method @GlobalScope.posmod] instead if you want to handle negative numbers. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, -20) % 7) # Prints "(3, -6)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) * Vector2i(3, 4)) # Prints "(30, 80)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [float] truncated to an integer. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) * 0.9) # Prints "(0, 0)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [int].

operator.name: operator +
operator.description: Adds each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) + Vector2i(3, 4)) # Prints "(13, 24)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator -
operator.description: Subtracts each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) - Vector2i(3, 4)) # Prints "(7, 16)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) / Vector2i(2, 5)) # Prints "(5, 4)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [float] truncated to an integer. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) / 2.9) # Prints "(5, 10)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [int].

operator.name: operator <
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than the X value of the [code]right[/code] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator <=
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than or equal to the X value of the [code]right[/code] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator ==
operator.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if the vectors are equal.

operator.name: operator >
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than the X value of the [code]right[/code] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator >=
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than or equal to the X value of the [code]right[/code] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator []
operator.description: Access vector components using their index. [code]v[0][/code] is equivalent to [code]v.x[/code], and [code]v[1][/code] is equivalent to [code]v.y[/code].

operator.name: operator unary+
operator.description: Returns the same value as if the [code]+[/code] was not there. Unary [code]+[/code] does nothing, but sometimes it can make your code more readable.

operator.name: operator unary-
operator.description: Returns the negative value of the [Vector2i]. This is the same as writing [code]Vector2i(-v.x, -v.y)[/code]. This operation flips the direction of the vector while keeping the same magnitude.
